docInfo.title: <STRICT EXTRACTION MODE: Extract the exact document title TRANSLATED in English. If there is no clear title, generate a short one based on the content.>
originalTitles: <Extract all unique titles exactly as written (cover/header/metadata). Keep original language/script. If none found, use empty array.>
docInfo.acronym: <Extract the acronym of the publishing/responsible organization/institution/owner ONLY if explicitly written (e.g., 'OECD', 'ERC'). Otherwise null.>

shortDescription.text: <STRICT: Use only text that appears verbatim in the document describing purpose/scope/audience - always translate in English. If no such text exists, generate one (50–120 words) from the document’s scope and purpose, without adding new facts: what the document is, who it is for, and why it matters. Emphasize decision/use value for researchers, policy makers, and research managers.>
shortDescription.generated: <boolean: false if the text is found verbatim in the document; true if synthesized>

abstract.text: <STRICT: Extract the abstract verbatim if an 'Abstract' (or equivalent section) exists - always translate in English. If not present, generate one (150–300 words), using only the information available in the text: scope/problem, approach/method (if any), key points/findings, and implications. Write in a neutral, evidence-aware style suitable for policy and research audiences.>
abstract.generated: <boolean: false if the text is found verbatim in the document; true if synthesized>

summary.text: <STRICT: Extract an executive summary/summary/conclusions section verbatim ONLY if explicitly present and clearly labeled - always translate in English. If not present, synthesize an executive-style summary of up to 300 words using document information only. Include: purpose, main conclusions, recommended actions or policy/management implications (if present), and any notable constraints/risks/limitations mentioned.>
summary.generated: <boolean: false if the text is found verbatim in the document; true if synthesized>

docInfo.startDate: <STRICT: If the document explicitly states a policy/program start year, extract YYYY. Otherwise null. Do not infer.>
docInfo.endDate: <STRICT: If the document explicitly states a policy/program end year, extract YYYY. Otherwise null. Do not infer.>
docInfo.publicationDate: <STRICT: Extract the publication year YYYY ONLY if explicitly stated (e.g., 'Published: 2023' or in citation block). If multiple years appear, choose the one explicitly labeled as publication/release. Otherwise null.>
organisations: <STRICT: List organizations explicitly named as responsible/publisher/authoring body. Use exact official names as written. If none, empty array.>
docInfo.country: <STRICT: Extract an explicit country or jurisdiction reference ONLY if clearly stated (e.g., 'Greece', 'Hellenic Republic') and convert to ISO 3166-1 alpha-2. If not, infer it from domain, language, or address unless the country name is written.>
docInfo.language: <STRICT: Detect language from the text and output ISO 639 code. If detection is uncertain, choose the closest and do not guess additional languages.>

authors.name: <STRICT: Extract author full names ONLY if explicitly listed. Otherwise leave authors as an empty array. Do not add editors/committees unless named individuals are listed.>
authors.orcid: <STRICT: Extract ORCID URL ONLY if explicitly present, exact format https://orcid.org/XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX. Otherwise null.>

docInfo.version: <STRICT: Extract version/edition ONLY if explicitly stated. Otherwise null.>
docInfo.modificationDate: <STRICT: Extract latest revision/modification date ONLY if explicitly stated (e.g., 'Last updated'). Preserve the exact string if formatting is unclear. Otherwise null.>

links.name: <STRICT: The link should be a page/document/dataset/resource - otherwise add it to 'otherLinks' section Extract the human-readable label associated with the link if present. If the link has no label, try to infer a relative name from the URL.>
links.pid: <STRICT: Extract a persistent identifier ONLY if explicitly written (DOI/Handle/ARK/URN/PURL/SWHID). Otherwise null.>
links.type: <STRICT: If pid exists, set type to one of: 'doi'/'handle'/'ark'/'purl'/'urn'/'swhid'. If pid is null and only a URL exists, set type to 'link' (do not classify as dataset/repository unless explicitly labeled as such in the document).>
links.url: <STRICT: Extract the URL exactly as written.>
links.description: <STRICT: Extract an accompanying description if it appears verbatim near the link. If none exists, generate a short description of linked document.>

otherLinks.name: <STRICT: Other links are links to social/news/feeds etc. Do not create links for emails. Extract the visible label of the link if present; If the link has no label, try to infer a relative name from the URL.>
otherLinks.type: <Use only if the document explicitly categorizes it (e.g., 'RSS', 'Twitter'). If not explicit, set 'other'.>
otherLinks.url: <STRICT: Extract the URL exactly as written.>
otherLinks.description: <Extract an accompanying description if it appears verbatim near the link. If none exists, generate a short description of linked document.>

tags: <STRICT: Choose ONLY from: ['national policy', 'university policy', 'use cases', 'strategy', 'RPO policy', 'RFO policy', 'survey', 'survey results'] AND ONLY if the document explicitly indicates the category (e.g., says 'strategy', 'survey results', 'policy'). If not explicit, leave empty array. | (RPO=Research Performing Organization, RFO=Research Funding Organization)>
otherTags: <STRICT: (1) include tags (translated in English) that are explicit keywords/headings/subject terms present in the document. (2) Generate a list of relevant tags based on document content. Combine (1),(2) and keep the 3-7 most relevant ones.>
